newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn signs rescheduling of 25 bln mark Russia debt.
newsitem.headline: Bonn signs rescheduling of 25 bln mark Russia debt.

text.p: Germany and Russia on Wednesday signed a pact to reschedule 25 billion marks in old Soviet debt for 20 to 25 years, the last such agreement, German finance minister Theo Waigel said.
"Parallel with other agreements with other members of the Paris Club (of creditors), the question of Soviet debt should finally be closed," Waigel said.
"We are finally seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Russia is paying its debts punctually and is returning to international capital markets," Waigel said.
Germany is Russia's largest foreign creditor, accounting for over half of its foreign debt.
Earlier this week, Russia announced it would launch a one billion mark Eurobond in early March as part of about $3 billion to be issued in Eurobonds this year.
The Bonn rescheduling, which was also signed by Russian Finance Minister Alexander Livshits, is the fourth since Russia agreed to take over the old Soviet debt in 1993.
It marks the bilateral implementation of a Paris Club agreement reached in April last year.
Waigel said the pact shows Germany's support for economic reforms in Russia, and recognition of its progress in curbing inflation, consolidating its budget and stabilising its currency.
"This pact is aimed at creating the conditions for sustainable economic development in Russia, and to allow it full access to international capital markets," Waigel said.
